list-item.p: Zika virus, a flavivirus, has re-emerged with intense outbreaks in the Americas since 2013.
It is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, primarily the species Aedes aegypti, but sexual transmission and transfusion-related transmission have also occurred.

It is often a mild or asymptomatic illness, but infections can manifest with rash, fever, conjunctivitis, and myalgias; severe manifestations have occurred and include Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS). In utero transmission has led to microcephaly and other severe birth defects.
There is no anti-viral agent to treat Zika virus infection; supportive care is indicated.

There is no effective vaccine yet; prevention relies on avoidance of vector mosquitoes and sexual contact with infected persons, which are particularly important for pregnant women and persons who are planning conception.
